channel.title: Take a Gigabyte off your Computer!
channel.description:
Take a Gigabyte off your Computer! by turning off hibernation. You can take more than a gigabyte off your computer depending on your memory. Some people have a gig, 2 gigs, 3 gigs, and more of memory!
First to see that I'm not lying. Go to My Computer and right click on your C:\ Drive and write down how many gigabytes of used space you have. I have 12.5 before I did hibernation.
Now to turn off hibernation (completely safe don't worry) just do this... 1. Right-click on the desktop and click on "Properties". 2. Click on the "Screen Saver" tab. 3. Click the "Power" button under "Monitor Power". 4. Click on the "Hibernation" tab, then uncheck the box next to "Enable Hibernation". 5. Press "OK" and you have just saved a load of hard drive space!
Source: http://www.geekstogo.com/forum/Easy_XP_Tweaks-t2780.html
Restart your computer, and then go to My Computer and right click on your C:\ Drive once again and compare your new used up space to your old one.
~Ron :D

item.title: Take a Gigabyte off your Computer!
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

You can take more than a gigabyte off your computer depending on your memory.

It’s depending on your memory. Most people have a gigabyte of memory or more.

256 memory is very unlikely. You need more memory sims!

And naww this isn’t really a tutorial, just a quick thing.

Read full topic

Surajd:

It’s only worth it, if you have Windows 98/ME with a very low spaced Hard-Drive

item.title: Take a Gigabyte off your Computer!
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

It works, but hibernation is a very useful function imo…if I have a ton of stuff open and I don’t want to reopen it the next day, I just leave my computer on hibernate. Maybe thats just laziness but I use it quiite often

But yes, if you don’t use it it can save a bit of hd space

Read full topic

@Ron wrote:

Now to turn off hibernation (completely safe don’t worry) just do this…

Restart your computer, and then go to My Computer and right click on your C:\ Drive once again and compare your new used up space to your old one.
